cleaned_text: colleagues wrote a journal article in, The New England Journal of Medicine, about Autism and the correlation that it has with vaccinations. The journal is, "A Population-Based Study of Measles, Mumps, and Rubella Vaccination and Autism." The journal was published November, 7, 2002. The collection of data was found over seven years using 537,303 children. Of those children, 440,655 received the MMR vaccine. The MMR vaccine is used to prevent the measles, mumps, and rubella diseases. Throughout the years, it has been implied that the reasoning behind autism was from giving children vaccines. Suggestions say that the increased use of the MMR vaccine correlated with an increase in autism. The research conducted was designed to follow up with all children born in Denmark between 1991 to 1998. The study only used the information from children 15 months old since that is the first administration of the vaccine within the time span of the study. "Of the 537,303 children in the cohort, 440,655 (82.0 percent) had received the MMR vaccine.
